Electron-deficient boronic acid catalyzed cyclization of CO2 and epoxides Xiaolin Jiang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Project administration Formal analysis Conceptualization a ⁎ 1 Liguang Zhang Writing – original draft Resources Project administration Investigation Data curation b 1 Shenglong Jiang Validation Data curation Conceptualization c Liwei Sun Resources Project administration Methodology Conceptualization c Yaru Zou Methodology Formal analysis d Yuehui Li Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization c ⁎ a School of Pharmacy, Shanghai University of Medicine and Health Sciences, Shanghai 201318, PR China School of Pharmacy, Shanghai University of Medicine and Health Sciences Shanghai 201318 PR China School of Pharmacy, Shanghai University of Medicine and Health Sciences, Shanghai 201318, PR China b Pharmacy College, Suzhou Vocational Health College, Suzhou 215009, PR China Pharmacy College, Suzhou Vocational Health College Suzhou 215009 PR China Pharmacy College, Suzhou Vocational Health College, Suzhou 215009, PR China c College of Smart Energy, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, PR China College of Smart Energy, Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 PR China College of Smart Energy, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, PR China d Department of Pharmacy, Children’s Hospital of Soochow University, Suzhou 215000, PR China Department of Pharmacy, Children’s Hospital of Soochow University Suzhou 215000 PR China Department of Pharmacy, Children’s Hospital of Soochow University, Suzhou 215000, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Utilizing CO2 as an abundant and low-cost C1 resource for the production of value-added chemicals is of significant industrial interest. This work introduces a metal-free cyclization of CO2 and epoxides into cyclic carbonates, catalyzed by electron-deficient, fluorine-substituted boronic acids under mild conditions. The catalysts demonstrate high activity and selectivity under mild condtions in non-polar solvents, with excellent compatibility with various functional groups such as heterocycle, alkene, phthalimide and chloride (13 examples, 53–95 % yields). The electron deficiency by F-substitution and the use of non-polar solvents enhance B-O interactions, allowing excellent catalytic performance and 6 times of catalyst recycling. This work highlights an effective strategy for CO2 utilization, advancing recyclable boronic acid catalysts in green chemistry. Graphical Abstract A highly efficient, metal-free approach for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides was achieved via catalysis of fluorine-substituted boronic acids. The catalysts demonstrate high activity and selectivity under mild condtions in non-polar solvents, with excellent compatibility with various functional groups. The B-O interactions between catalyst and substrate were proposed to play crucial roles for the excellent catalytic performance. Keywords Cyclic carbonates Boronic acid catalyst CO2 utilization B-O interaction F-substitution Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Cyclic carbonates are important solvents of Li-battery and valuable compounds widely used in the production of polymers, pharmaceuticals, and fine chemicals [1,2]. Traditional synthetic routes often rely on hazardous reagents like phosgene, prompting the need for safer, more sustainable alternatives. The cycloaddition of carbon dioxide (CO2) with epoxides has emerged as an attractive strategy, utilizing CO2 as a low-cost C1 feedstock to produce valuable chemicals. This approach not only avoids toxic reagents but also offers the dual benefit of CO2 utilization and the generation of carbon-neutral products, making it highly relevant for sustainable chemical processes [3–5]. The selective activation of CO2 and epoxides requires rational design of multifunctional catalysts. Traditional metal-based catalysts for this cycloaddition reaction, such as zinc, cobalt, or aluminum complexes, often face limitations such as high costs, toxicity, and poor recyclability [6–9]. As a result, there has been growing interest in exploring non-metallic catalysts due to their advantages in cost-effectiveness, environmental safety, and tunability [10–13]. Recent studies have shown that non-metallic catalysts, such as ionic liquids containing imidazole and bromine, polyphenolic compounds, and organic boron-containing molecules, are promising alternatives for catalyzing the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides [14–25]. In 2017, Mu and collaborators pioneered the use of a binary catalyst system consisting of potassium iodide (KI) and boron phosphate (BPO4) for this reaction. In this system, BPO4 acts as both a Brønsted and Lewis acid, facilitating the activation of the epoxy ring through hydrogen bonding and significantly enhancing the catalytic activity of KI for the cycloaddition reaction ( Scheme 1A) [15]. Liu and coworkers reported another binary system comprising tetrahydroxydiboron and tetrabutylammonium iodide (TBAI), where tetrahydroxydiboron exhibits dual activation effects on both CO2 and epoxides. Initially, it forms a boron-CO2 adduct, followed by epoxide activation through interaction with the B-O bond (Scheme 1B) [17]. Zhang and collaborators found 2,6-substituted arylboronic acid behaved as a strong hydrogen-bonding donor. It is the first time that boronic acid acts as a Brønsted acid catalyst in the reaction of CO2 with epoxide (Scheme 1C) [18]. However, the use of water arises the limitations related to the stability issue of both epoxides and boronic acids under heating conditions [26]. The modular nature of boronic acid catalysts allows for easy tuning of their structures and properties to optimize catalytic performance. The introduction of the fluorine (F) group offers further electronic stabilization and steric control, enhancing both solubility and catalytic recyclability, ultimately leading to improved performance. In this context, the present study focuses on the development of fluorine-containing boronic acid catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates in non-polar solvents (Scheme 1). Notably, the use of non-polar solvents may enable catalyst recycling in boronic acid-catalyzed reactions. However, previous studies have focused on using water as solvent, without investigating recyclability of the molecular catalyst [18]. This catalytic system presents several key advantages: it is operated under metal-free and mild reaction conditions, exhibits high catalytic activity, and offers excellent cyclicity, all while being compatible with non-polar solvents. Through systematic experimental investigations, we aim to elucidate the reaction mechanism, optimize the catalytic performance, and explore the broader applicability of this system in sustainable chemical synthesis. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Optimization of the reaction conditions Based on our recent work on developing new catalysts for synthesis of cyclic carbonates [27–29] and arylborate catalysts for CO2 activation [30], we embarked on investigating small molecules especially containing boron as catalysts for synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides. Initially, various molecules containing active proton were tested while selecting styrene oxide (1a) as model substrate for screening of catalyst structure and optimization of reaction conditions, and the results are summarized in Table 1. When phenol was used as catalyst with chlorobenzene as solvent and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) as co-catalyst, we found only a trace amount of the desired product was determined (Table 1, entry 1); when using thiols, no desired product was formed (Table 1, entry 2). However, when using aromatic carboxylic acids as catalyst, the yield was achieved at 20 % (Table 1, entry 3), indicating active hydrogen contained compounds as promising catalysts for the reaction of CO2. We further screened phenylboronic acid as a catalyst in chlorobenzene solvent and found that phenylboronic acid has a higher catalytic activity yield of 34 % for the reaction of epoxides and CO2 to form cyclic carbonates (Table 1, entry 4). A blank experiment conducted without the catalyst failed to produce any detectable amount of cyclic carbonate (Table 1, entry 5), highlighting the essential role of the boronic acid catalyst. Since the choice of solvent plays a critical role in small-molecule catalysis, we systematically screened various solvents. We observed significant differences in yield depending on the solvent's properties. Solvents commonly used for epoxide-to-carbonate transformations showed good activity (Table 1, entries 6 and 7). However, in polar proton solvents, the reaction did not proceed (Table 1, entry 8). This inhibition is likely due to the solvent quenching the activation effect of the boronic acid catalyst on the epoxide, thus preventing the reaction. Notably, the highest yield was achieved using the non-polar solvent n-heptane (Table 1, entry 10), which was chosen as the optimal solvent for further studies. We then tested a series of boronic acids, which yielded varying results (Table 1, entries 11–19). For example, when 4-chloroboronic acid was used, styrene oxide was converted to cyclic carbonate with a moderate yield of 48 %, slightly lower than that of unsubstituted boronic acid (Table 1, entry 15 vs. entry 10). Encouraged by this result, we further explored the effects of halogen substitutions and their positions on the boronic acid. Among the tested catalysts, 4-fluorophenylboronic acid provided the highest yield (Table 1, entry 16), and the turnover frequency (TOF) is 8.8 h−1. In our recent work involving CO2 utilization, it was found that KF can significantly promote the cleavage of C-O bonds[31]. The reaction conditions were subsequently optimized, and an excellent yield of 95 % was obtained when the reaction was carried out at 60 °C for 6 h, and the total turnover number (TON) is 24 (Table 1, entry 20). Interestingly, 1,4-benzenediboronic acid proved ineffective for the cycloaddition reaction (Table 1, entry 19), possibly due to steric hindrance or electronic effects that interfered with catalyst-substrate interactions. These findings demonstrate that both the choice of solvent and the specific structure of the boronic acid catalyst significantly impact the catalytic efficiency and overall reaction outcome. 2.2 Substrate scope of the reaction With the optimal reaction conditions in hand, we explored the scope and limitations of the boronic acid-catalyzed synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides, as shown in Table 2. Various epoxides were successfully transformed, giving the corresponding cyclic carbonates in excellent yields (2a-2m). Both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents exhibit significant activity. However, cyclohexyl epoxide provided cyclic carbonates in only 25 % and 13 % yields (2k, 2l), likely due to the steric hindrance of the cyclohexyl ring. Epoxides with succinimide and carbazole heterocyclic substituents also gave good yields (2g, 93 %; 2i, 82 %), demonstrating the method's broad applicability. Additionally, increasing the reaction temperature to 100 °C and extending the time to 12 h improved the yields for cyclohexyl epoxide (2k, 69 %; 2l, 53 %). We believe this improvement is due to overcoming the steric hindrance of the cyclohexyl ring at higher temperatures. 2.3 Mechanism studies To gain further insight into the mechanism of this transformation, we examined the interactions between boronic acid, TBAB, styrene oxide, and CO2 using NMR spectroscopy. The 11B NMR spectrum (128 MHz, CDCl3) showed a peak at 29.4 ppm, corresponding to the boron atom in phenylboronic acid, while a new peak at 30.0 ppm suggested that TBAB interacted with phenylboronic acid, likely through H-Br hydrogen bonding. Literature reports support this, indicating that phenylboronic acid and TBAB can form a crystal structure with strong hydrogen bonding between the bromide of TBAB and the hydrogen atom of boronic acid [32]. Additionally, a downfield shift to 31.9 ppm was observed, which may be attributed to interactions between boronic acid and the oxygen in styrene oxide. In the presence of CO2, a small shoulder peak at 30.1 ppm emerged, indicating the interaction between CO2 and the boron atom ( Fig. 1). In the 1H NMR experiments, the addition of styrene oxide to phenylboronic acid resulted in unchanged chemical shifts for the aromatic hydrogen atoms, indicating a weak and dynamic electrostatic B-O interaction. On the other hand, upon mixing phenylboronic acid with TBAB, the aromatic C-H signals exhibited an upfield shift (e.g., from 7.63 to 7.53 ppm for the hydrogen atom para to the boron atom), which can be attributed to hydrogen bonding interactions between the bromide ion and the aromatic C-H bonds (see the Supporting Information). Based on these NMR findings, we propose the following reaction mechanism ( Fig. 2). Initially, intermediate A is formed through hydrogen bonding between TBAB and phenylboronic acid, as indicated by previous literature reports[32]. This interaction activates the B-O-H bond, which coordinates with the oxygen atom of the epoxide, increasing the electrophilicity of the carbon atoms in the epoxide ring. The activation of epoxide through B-O interaction which is supported by DRIFTS study [33] is then followed by attack of the bromide ion nearby, leading to the formation of a six-membered ring intermediate (C). Subsequently, C undergoes C-O bond cleavage, and CO2 is introduced, forming a carbonate anion intermediate (E). Intermediate F then undergoes ring opening and cyclization, ultimately forming the cyclic carbonate product with the release of bromide (Fig. 2). 2.4 Catalyst recycling experiment Preliminary kinetic studies provided further mechanistic insights ( Fig. 3A). Styrene oxide (1a) was almost fully converted into the cyclic carbonate product (2a) within six hours. There is almost no incubation period for the catalyst. Additionally, the 4-F-boronic acid catalyst was tested at 4 mol% loading in a batch mode over six recycling cycles for the cycloaddition process of propylene oxide, which is the most concerned in industry. It maintained a yield of 70 % (GC yield) with a TOF of 11.2 h−1 and a TON of over 400 achieved (Fig. 3B). After each cycle, the catalyst was retained by evaporation, washed with heptane, and reused without further drying, demonstrating excellent recyclability. 3 Conclusion In conclusion, we have successfully demonstrated that F-containing boronic acid catalysts exhibit high efficiency in promoting the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to form cyclic carbonates. The use of metal-free catalysts under mild, recyclable conditions presents a promising and sustainable strategy for CO2 utilization. The catalysts demonstrate high activity and selectivity in non-polar solvents, with excellent compatibility with various functional groups such as heterocycle, alkene, phthalimide and chloride (13 examples, 53–95 % yields). The tunable electronic and steric properties of the boron atom further enhance the catalytic performance, offering flexibility for optimization in various applications. This work provides a green, efficient pathway for cyclic carbonate synthesis and contributes meaningfully to advancing sustainable CO2 conversion technologies. coredata.dc:description: Utilizing CO2 as an abundant and low-cost C1 resource for the production of value-added chemicals is of significant industrial interest. This work introduces a metal-free cyclization of CO2 and epoxides into cyclic carbonates, catalyzed by electron-deficient, fluorine-substituted boronic acids under mild conditions. The catalysts demonstrate high activity and selectivity under mild condtions in non-polar solvents, with excellent compatibility with various functional groups such as heterocycle, alkene, phthalimide and chloride (13 examples, 53–95 % yields). The electron deficiency by F-substitution and the use of non-polar solvents enhance B-O interactions, allowing excellent catalytic performance and 6 times of catalyst recycling. This work highlights an effective strategy for CO2 utilization, advancing recyclable boronic acid catalysts in green chemistry.

coredata.dc:title: Electron-deficient boronic acid catalyzed cyclization of CO2 and epoxides
